moves.3. d4: [%clk 0:05:03] Not the most common answer, but one of the best.
moves.4... Bxe6: [%clk 0:05:13] The point is black has two developed pieces and white none. It is actually not such a great advantage, though, and has to be handled carefully. I didn't.
moves.5... Nbd7: [%clk 0:05:14] Not forced still to employ the dsb on e7. I like it on d6. Now white can go d5, and if Bxd5, QxB, NxQ, BxQ, and black has Nb4 as a threat, forcing Bd6, NxB, cxN, after which black has still RxBd8 and is in good shape.
moves.6... Bd6: [%clk 0:05:07] Where I want it. Of course white can reject it with c4-c5. Two tempos, and I can still go c6 and Bb4+.
moves.7. Bd3: [%clk 0:04:47] I would say this is too passive.
moves.7... h6: [%clk 0:05:09] I plan all the way to castle queenside, so I'm not scared in opening the kingside. By playing this, I accept Bh4, g5 and the risky piece per two pawns sac. A fun game, the result difficult to predict. I also accept Bg3, and I will answer Qe7 and leave the exchange to him.
moves.8. Be3: [%clk 0:04:45] Does this look like a bad move?
moves.9. O-O: [%clk 0:04:48] Thank you white. Can you see you are inviting me?
moves.10. h3: [%clk 0:04:49] c4 was strongly needed, in order to force the deployment of my dsb (I'll go to f4 in case of c5). This is a mistake, even fearing Ng4, because it opens the way to my g pawn.
moves.10... O-O-O: [%clk 0:05:14] Maybe too slow, but hey, I'm losing too many games no to be a little wiser.
moves.11. c3: [%clk 0:04:45] ?? c4 was definitely needed. I later understood his plan, that is to open the way for his Q to a4, threatening a7. This plan will prove to be a frustrating one for white. Let's see why.
moves.11... g5: [%clk 0:05:17] Last chance for white to "open the umbrella". g4 is threatened, opening the K's shield.
moves.12. Qa4: [%clk 0:04:24] White bets for the counterattack. Who will get a deathly threat before? Now, when the game is like this, you have to give sooo much importance to tempoes. In this particular case, even after Qxa7, Qa8+, I have essentially nothing to fear in the short term.
moves.12... g4: [%clk 0:05:07] So I go on with my attack, ignoring his! A breach in pawns or a piece, white: choose!
moves.13. hxg4: [%clk 0:03:59] A deadly breach is opened in white king's front. Now: which one should take? N or B?
moves.13... Bxg4: [%clk 0:04:46] The idea is that this B will be backed by a R, threatening the N. White's marvelous B pair is almost useless!
moves.14. Ne5: [%clk 0:03:54] What else? Kh1 was a chance to bring in the R on g1. Would you say black has an edge here... ? :-)
moves.16... Rdg8: [%clk 0:04:46] Why not the other R? I thought I had to avoid Bxh6 to ensure my dominion on the g file. I was wrong, in fact Bxh6 guarantees me the win.
moves.17... Bf3: [%clk 0:04:26] "Incidentally", this covers Ra1+. It does allow Bf4+. But, incredibly this is not a problem due to white's Nb1, which prevents white to connect R.
moves.19... Kd8: [%clk 0:04:21] Not Nd7. It covers d7. But in playing this, I invited (with some malice, I admit) my opponent in playing...
moves.20. Bb6: [%clk 0:01:31] "Oooooohhhhh!" makes the lady "my hero is in danger" :-D but I reply: "Don't worry, baby, just relax and look..."
moves.20... Bf4+: [%clk 0:03:53] Is this a beauty or not? I know, not a big deal, but "live" it is nice to have found it.
